instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.P1V05S0_EN: What is P1V05S0_EN? P1V05S0_EN is a signal that enables the PP1V05_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP5V_SO: What is PP5V_SO? PP5V_SO is a typo of PP5V_S0, which is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state. The person who typed PP5V_SO thought that the S0 in PP5V_S0 was SO, if you see PP5V_SO assume the user made a typo and meant to type PP5V_S0.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message:
hi
I am new to apple board fixing sow please be gentle. I have fixed other type of motherboards but no apple mb until now.
I have this mb: green light on charger for few second after turn to orange (with no battery connected) and no fan spin ( i think this is normal at this model).
i have noticed a little area (like a drop of water) with corrosion on the following components :
<RESISTOR>R7742</RESISTOR> ( 0 ohm had to replace) and
<RESISTOR>R7752</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7753</RESISTOR> ( no component on motherboard only pad corroded)
there is no other area corroded , i have cleaned the board with ultrasound .... still nothing.
i have the following voltages and now i am stuck :

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> 12.58
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER5V</SIGNAL> 12.58
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL> 12.58
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S4_X239</SIGNAL> 0.00
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S4_TPAD</SIGNAL> 0.00
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> 15.17
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 14.59
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.41
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.34
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5.024
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.348
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.347
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> 1.060
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.4 v


<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>  0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> 0v


<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 0v

<CHIP>U8000</CHIP>, <CHIP>U8050</CHIP> area is like new

around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PP5_S3_REG</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_DRVH</SIGNAL> 3,3v
ppbus_s5_hs_ other3v3 12,5v
<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREG</SIGNAL> 3,25v
<SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> 3,4v
<SIGNAL>SG_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3,37v
<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_SKIPSEL</SIGNAL> 1,98v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_CSP2</SIGNAL> 3,32v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_CSN2</SIGNAL> 3,31v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_VFB2</SIGNAL> 1,8v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_COMP2</SIGNAL> 1,95v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREF2</SIGNAL> 1,98v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 3,4v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_COMP1</SIGNAL> 1,98v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_VFB1</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_CSN1</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_CSP2</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S3_PGOOD</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_RF</SIGNAL> 1,24v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_DRVH</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_LL</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_VBST</SIGNAL> 4,78v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_DRVL</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_DRVL</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_VBST</SIGNAL> 8,30v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_LL</SIGNAL> 3,31v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_DRVH</SIGNAL> 3,32v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL> 12,54v

on pin 3 (<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>) <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_RF</SIGNAL> is 1,24v ..... it is normal? not 3,3 v?

not sure this is relevant but <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL>   3.4v


i would appreciate any idea pls.... i am stuck
THX

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: Inspect <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area for corrosion. Are you using a 60W charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message:
no corrosion  the area is like new ..
Charger is 60w and is the original one
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is present on pin 8
Thx

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: allso the area around <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is clean  and no pads are corroded

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message:
Measure carefully on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> and see if there is a pules(s) right after connecting power. If not check PPVRTC.
Best to check this with a scope as multimeters are slow especially auto range ones.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message:
just when i connect the charger <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is jumping once  an then stays down  
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.32v   constant

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: Check for shorts on s3 and s0 rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message:
on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  i have noticed that i have only 10.6 ohm  to ground  and, on diode measurement i have 0.0006v,  is this normal ? or the problem is around this ....
THX

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: i got this when i measure on L7310 and L7320  and <CAPACITOR>C1088</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: sorry to many zero  0.006v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: i have measured all s0 and s3 rails and  no short to ground .....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: Does it run in SMC bypass mode? Hold down power button, plug in magsafe, wait 3 seconds, release power button, press power button again (should have a solid green light and fans will spin maximum)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: How does pin 8 on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> look?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message:
pin 8 on u 1950 is clean and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is present,
in smc bypass mode:
I hold the power button  connect the charger  - amber light, release button - solid green , press button nothing happens.(green turns to amber)
i have noticed that also <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is jumping when i connect the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: So CPU Vcore is pulsing. This usually means there is an issue with the SPI lines. Check all termination resistors and traces between them that go to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: sorry my english is not so good. it is not pulsing only one jump when i connect the charger ... same thing whit other s0 and s3 voltages for example with <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_EN</SIGNAL>, and the SPI lines are ok, clean and all the resistors have the correct values

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: Check all voltage rails for shorts to GND.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message:
i have check  2 times for a short on all voltage rails and i was unable to find any shorts
bu t i have noticed  that
on pin 16 (<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>) there is 1.02v  but  before <RESISTOR>R7562</RESISTOR> is 3.3v . on the schematic  says  3.3v  it is that ok ?
<SIGNAL>P5V_S5EN</SIGNAL> is 3.4v ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: also on schematic <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL>  is 8.5 v but i have 12.5v    is that normal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message:
PPBUS should be 12.6. I don't think you understand how <RESISTOR>R7562</RESISTOR> circuit works.....

There is nothing I can do for this one but say termination resistors and traces in <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> circuit, pin 8 on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. It could be 100 other things, inspect the board carefully. Pulsing power is THE worst issue to diagnose.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message:
ieee I am the lucky one :( my first apple mb and is a nightmare
THX

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> i have noticed that i have only 10.6 ohm to ground and, on diode measurement i have 0.0006v, is this normal ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message:
I have noticed that on <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCSENSE_N</SIGNAL> i have 0 volts to the ground ( on diode measurement) and 1.1 ohm to the ground,  both <CAPACITOR>C7261</CAPACITOR> and  <RESISTOR>R0960</RESISTOR> are ok is that normal ?
on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> i have  12.53 on pin 17 and 0.52 on pin 8(<SIGNAL>CPUVR_FB2</SIGNAL>)  nothing else

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message:
That is all normal. Power is pulsing so system is trying to boot up but fails. As said this could be 100 different thing. Most likely cases are <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and termination resistors/traces, crap under SMC, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8 or damaged/corroded resistor somewhere.
Nothing more really can be done in this case. Maybe upload some high-res pictures for assessment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>THANK_U</SIGNAL> for your patience.
After looking again and again through microscope seems that the only area with corrosion is <RESISTOR>R7752</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7753</RESISTOR> (seen in picture)
I also noticed that the only rails that are not jumping is <SIGNAL>PP5V_SO</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_VMON</SIGNAL>  ( neither of these have short to ground)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2015 Retina 13in green light on charger no power on need some help
threads.message: I still have no other ideas for you. <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> has more to it than just that picture......
